description.narrative: This project is an extension of PIGGAREP, to promotes low carbon development for Pacific SIDS. In particular, this project includes the following initiatives: SolGen in Cook Islands, and BioGen in Kiribati and Samoa.

description.narrative: Enhancing Resilience of Coastal Communities to Climate Change Risks to strengthen the ability of Samoa communities and public service to make informed decisions in a pro-active, integrated and strategic manner.
capital of a political entity
Number of risk-exposed coastal communities protected through coastal adaptation measures based on climate-sensitive Coastal Infrastructure Management Plans (CIMP)

comment.narrative: In the lack of systematic implementation of CIM Plans, the target villages and districts are highly exposed to climate-induced hazards

- Procure the CIMP Review team - Initiate the Small Grants Component - Procure the Resettlement Specialist to complete the resettlement handbook/roadmap as well as the hazard relocation handbooks for 15 villages. - Conduct the Institutional Review for the Ministry and the CIMP - Climate proof identified roads and coastal protection based upon the TAG recommendation i.e. LTA

- 6 of the CIMP Review Team was recruited and the review consultation in the first 5 districts in Savaii was completed In November 2016. (Team Leader, Civil Engineer, Geomorphologist, Livelihood Specialist, Ecosystem Specialist and the Translator). - The MoU between CSSP and MNRE was signed in December 2016 and is valid for 12 months. The Small Grants Officer was recruited through UNDP and then handed over to the Government for Contract. She is officially onboard the first 50% of the Small Grants Component was released upon signing of the MoU. The AF Small Grants Unit was set up in CSSP Office and the first consultation and programme is scheduled to move early 2017. - The UNDP via LoA and upon request from the GoS recruited the Resettlement Specialist, he was able to provide the draft Resettlement strategy (later revised to be considered as a Guideline or Roadmap instead of a strategy) - The Institutional Review for MNRE and the CIMPs began in September 2016 upon the procurement of the specialist. - The launch for Saleia and Manase embankment was completed in Savaii. This was a co-financed project with ICCRITS. The road works for Fusi, Tufutafoe and Muifanua completed.

- Complete the CIMP Consultation in 25 districts of AF project - Complete and Finalize the CIMP Drafts for at least 20 Districts. - Complete all the technical reports to feed into the CIMP i.e. TAs recruited for the CIMP Review to provide reports. - Complete and finalize the Resettlement Handbooks (15) and the Relocation Guide. - Complete and finalize the Institutional Arrangement for MNRE and CIMPs. - Approve at least 20 small grants projects and implement and complete at least 10 SG Projects. - Complete the Communication Strategy; - Post atleast 4 stories from the project on relevant media outlets. - Finalize the tenders and BoQ for the remaining roads selected by the GoS Climate Steering Committee.

-The consultation process for the 25 districts of AF is completed successfully by the CIMP Team and the GoS relevant counterparts. - To date (Nov 2017), 5 draft CIMP have been finalized and another 5 submitted for review. In total 10 drafts received for 10 districts. - All the TAs hired as part of the CIMP team have completed and submitted all their technical review reports except the Team Leader and the Spatial and DRM specialist hired in 2017 to complete the maps. - The Ministry have received the 15 hazard zone resettlement plans for 15 villages. The Relocation Strategy that is now considered to be called a guide or a roadmap for the country is also completed. - The Institutional Strengthening Specialist hired to complete this task has indeed completed institutional arrangement and have submitted to the CEO of MNRE as well as the PSC for consideration. - The Small Grants have mobilized nicely and have completed the call for proposal for both Savaii and Upolu. They have reviewed, shortlisted and completed the site visit to the proposed sites and have awarded more than 20 small grants to the communities that applied for the grant. - A communication Specialist was hired in Q3 2017 and have completed and submitted the draft Communication Strategy suggested int he MTE report to be completed. - 3 stories was posted on Samoa Observer, Twitter and Facebook for the project i.e. Small grants stories for both Savaii and Upolu and the CIMP consultation stories in the paper as well. - The Land Transport Authority have finalized the BoQ and tender process for Salelologa but Taelefaga and Musumusu Coastal Protection is being tendered at the moment. It is envisioned that the contractors will be onboard for the latter in December. Salelologa Township roads is scheduled to complete its works in Dec or Early Jan 2018.

title.narrative: Strengthening Multi-Sectoral Management of Critical Land

description.narrative: The project aims to strengthen local capacities, incentives and actions for integrated landscape management in order to reduce land degradation, greenhouse gas emissions, promote nature conservation whilst enhancing sustainable local livelihoods in Samoa

capital of a political entity

1. Area under increased vegetative cover (with average of tree density of 111/Ha) 2. Area under forest cover (no net loss due to landuse conversion) under effective management 3. Increase of agriculture income and consumption per household as a consequence of increased productivity of land 4. Area of natural forests, riverine areas and wetlands under formal community protection
Outcome 1 1. Number of certified organic farmers/farms 2. Increased density and diversity of native tree species in cyclone damaged landscapes around Apia covering 3314 ha 3. Area of natural forests, riverine areas and wetlands under protection and management in the production landscape under community landuse plans (forest and tree cover maintenance; maintenance of wetlands; no net increase of agricultural land under mono cropping) 4. Number of farmer households adopting at least one or more soil / water management and conservation practices on agricultural lands 5. comment.narrative:
Project Objective: 1. 135,000Ha 2. 128,000Ha 3. USD 2,692 on average 4. Total National emissions from AFOLU 135.37, Gg CO@-e (2007).27
Outcome1: 1. 606 certified currently exist; 345 in Savaii & 261 in Upolu 2. With recent damage by TC Evans, baseline will be determined when project start. 3. 0 4. There are 10790 households in the target area of the project, but with limited soil and water conservation activities 5. Water quality at sampled sites (3 major sites) shows confirmed incidences of E.coli presence exceeding national standards 6. Estimated 30000 livestock in target areas, covering 5000 ha 7. No village plans incorporating SLM 8. No reports on knowledge on SLM
Outcome 2: 9. No soil management and conservation manual 10. A number of policies and plans to support SLM (see section 1.5 of the project document) but inter-sectoral approach is weak 11. 3 12. No coordination mechanisms for SLM 13. SFA and WIBDI NGOs assisting communities with projects that are SLM compatible. 14. No SLM information system 15. No SLM training currently available at USP for government staff 16. No SLM courses available at University for undergraduate students

Project Objective: 1. 24,430 ha [This figure is based on 18,930 ha of changes in current agricultural land-use practices and at least 5,000 hectares of degraded lands restored through community activities and further 500 hectares will be forests] 2. 164,000 ha 3. 5000 households incomes increase by 10% on average by project end through increased land productivity 4. Avoided emission of 689333 CO2-eq for 4 years and sequestration of store additionally 10,755 tCO2eq.
Outcome1: 1. A 30% increase in number of households engaged in organic farming or more ecological farming 2. At least 50% increase forest cover in a landscape 3. By the end of the project, at least 55000 ha will be under integrated landscape management outside KBAs 4. At least 5000 households will be adopting soil management and conservation practices in their land by the end of the project covering at least 18000 ha 5. At least 50% of the project sites report on increased water quality by the end of the project including E. coli levels within national standards; and additional parameters of nutrient loads (such as nitrogen) are also within acceptable international standards 6. At least 50% relocated, covering 2500 ha 7. At least 50 villages have developed plans integrating SLM with the participation of 15000 community member including men, women and young 8. At least 40% of the communities are able to report on increased knowledge on SLM through access to national SLM system, audio-video materials and trainings
Outcome 2: 9. By the end of year 1 a Soil management and conservation manual developed including SLM practices for agriculture, forestry and water resources management 10. Land Resource management legislation developed and national landuse policy updated. Agriculture Sector Plan 2011-2016 strengthen to mainstream SLM approaches and management practices policies on mining (including sand mining) strengthened or developed formal guidelines for sustainable land management under village develo

Project Objective 1. The following statistics reflect the level of engagement of the eight (8) target communities in the project components: a. KBA surveys: Close to two hundred (200) villagers were consulted and close to a hundred (100) took part in the preliminary survey and the preparation of transects for the comprehensive biodiversity assessment survey because of their traditional knowledge and practical experiences with the four (4) target KBAs. b. Sustainable Agriculture Practices and Landscape Farm Plan Training Programme (SAPLFPTP): More than a hundred (100+) took part in the SAPLFPTP with eight (8) of them that have established landscape farm plans that will be implemented from the third quarter (July - September) of this year 2016 with assistance from the project. c. Livestock (cattle, pigs & poultry) Farm Relocation and or Buffering from Catchments: Close to a hundred (100) villagers were consulted with three (3) of them that have agreed and were selected to develop and implement plans for the relocation and or buffering of their cattle farm from catchments with the project assistance from the third quarter (July - September) of this year 2016. 2. The following steps were started for this outcome: 1) Plans are underway for the assessment and rehabilitation of the thirteen (13) acres of highly vulnerable catchment lands at Malololelei of the Apia Catchment that was taken under the Taking of Land Act for Public Purpose 1964 with the project's assistance in 2015. 2) The project have identified the Apia Catchment as the target area for the development of a first Payment for Ecosystem Services or PES Scheme for Samoa as a result of the first phase of the PES consultancy and plans are underway in a second phase of the PES consultancy to implement this in the remaining quarters of 2016. This step will contribute to the rehabilitation activities such as the replanting of the Apia catchments with native and indigenous species from the 2017 with the proj

Project Objective: 1. 24,430 ha [This figure is based on 18,930 ha of changes in current agricultural land-use practices and at least 5,000 hectares of degraded lands restored through community activities and further 500 hectares will be forests] 2. 164,000 ha 3. 5000 households incomes increase by 10% on average by project end through increased land productivity 4. Avoided emission of 689333 CO2-eq for 4 years and sequestration of store additionally 10,755 tCO2eq.
Outcome1: 1. A 30% increase in number of households engaged in organic farming or more ecological farming 2. At least 50% increase forest cover in a landscape 3. By the end of the project, at least 55000 ha will be under integrated landscape management outside KBAs 4. At least 5000 households will be adopting soil management and conservation practices in their land by the end of the project covering at least 18000 ha 5. At least 50% of the project sites report on increased water quality by the end of the project including E. coli levels within national standards; and additional parameters of nutrient loads (such as nitrogen) are also within acceptable international standards 6. At least 50% relocated, covering 2500 ha 7. At least 50 villages have developed plans integrating SLM with the participation of 15000 community member including men, women and young 8. At least 40% of the communities are able to report on increased knowledge on SLM through access to national SLM system, audio-video materials and trainings
Outcome 2: 9. By the end of year 1 a Soil management and conservation manual developed including SLM practices for agriculture, forestry and water resources management 10. Land Resource management legislation developed and national landuse policy updated. Agriculture Sector Plan 2011-2016 strengthen to mainstream SLM approaches and management practices policies on mining (including sand mining) strengthened or developed formal guidelines for sustainable land management under village develo

Project Objective: 1. a. Forest replanting and ecosystem restoration for degraded watershed area which now turn into Malolelei BioPark initiative, and Mt Vaea Scenic Reserves already covering 16.3ha with an estimated total of native tree seedlings planted at 33,700, that's a density of 2,067 per ha; b. Plus 7,600 native tree seedlings raised at the Vailima Botanical Garden nurseries to support restoration and rehabilitation works; c. Five (5) project villages with SLM plans formulated (Uafato, Safaato'a, Samamea, Apolima-Tai & Samusu) have forest replanting components which are currently under implementation. Tree planting has already implemented for Safaato village covering 0.4ha and plans are underway for community tree planting components of the other four (4) target villages. 2. a. Approximately 85,000 ha of three KBAs (ie. Falealupo Coast Rainforest 12,000 ha, Central Savaii 72,000 ha and Uafato-Tiavea Coastal Rainforest 1,306 ha) were surveyed in July-August 2016s BIORAP including the completion of the Traditional Knowledge Survey (TEK) with the survey reports completed as first step to the development of the KBA Management Plans of these KBA in the country; b. Ecological restoration of degraded areas and forest rehabilitation program through promoting native tree planting restoration on national reserves ie. Mt Vaea Scenic Reserves and Malolelei BioPark has so far reached 33,700 seedlings planted covering 16.3 ha of land areas; c. Newly established Community Conservation Areas (CCAs) for the village of Gataivai (12 ha) and Taga (10ha) on Savaii Islands under FPAM as co-finance covering 22 ha in total; d. Village/Community Forest Replanting Training Manual and Programme drafted -Trainers Guide & Participants Content Booklet - in Samoan. 3. a. Awaiting the consultancy for the validation of the target and the development of the appropriate Monitoring Protocol to determine the measurement of the income increase of the target with the local farmers and land

title.narrative: Enhancing the Resilience of Tourism-reliant Communities

description.narrative: Enhancing the Resilience of Tourism-reliant Communities to Climate Change Risks in Samoa Project

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDPs results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDPs projects contributed to
Number of preparedness plans that cover only response
Enhancing the Resilience of Tourism-reliant Communities to Climate Change Risks in Samoa Project
populated place
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

Capacity perception index of STA disaggregated by gender; AMAT 2.2.2) (1=no capacity built 2=initial awareness raised 3=substantial training in practical application 4=knowledge effectively transferred 5=ability to apply or disseminate knowledge demonstrated)
% of tourism operators who invest and implement sustainable adaptation measures to enhance their resilience.
Outcome 1 - # of Management Plans developed and operationalized - % of tourism operators in targeted TDAs apply new guidelines for climate resilient actions - # of tourism operators that gain access to financial products for climate resilient actions
Outcome 2 - Number and type of risk reduction activities introduced in tourism reliant communities (AMAT 2.3.1.1); - % of women and men in tourism reliant communities trained in climate risk reduction; - % of targeted tourism reliant communities that have adopted climate resilient livelihoods.

comment.narrative:
Capacity of STA is currently rated at 2-3.
Tourism operators are not investing in sustainable adaptation measures, but instead in quick and unsustainable measures to cope with climate risks
Outcome 1 - Climate resilient management plans are currently not in place - No guidelines exist for effective no-regrets adaptation measures to increase resilience of tourism operators and there is a history of little application of guidelines is commonly low - Tourism operators do not access financial products for climate resilient actions
Outcome 2 - No Operators with Business plans which incorporate climate smart risk assessment & planning; - nitial awareness raising activities have taken place in the project area under the PPG phase, but no systematic training has been provided on; - Apart from some ad- hoc measures individuals are taking, none of the targeted communities have climate resilient livelihoods

Outcome 1 - By the end of the project, at least 6 climate resilient management plans have been developed and operationalized per TDA, involving at least 20 villages in total. - By the end of the project, at least 75% of the targeted tourism operators apply the issued guidelines; - By the end of the project, at least 15 operators have successfully gained access to financial products for climate resilient actions
Outcome 2 - At least five risk reduction activities have been introduced across the 9 villages in the 6 TDAs; - By the end of the project at least 50% of the women and 50% of the men of the targeted communities has been trained in climate risk reduction. - By the end of the project at least 80% of the targeted communities have adopted climate resilient livelihoods.

Outcome 1 -6 management plans have been launched and disbursed to individual TDAs -More than 75% of tourism operators are applying the issued guidelines through proposed projects under the small grants scheme. - A total of 16 operators were awarded financial access in round 1 od the small grants scheme alone and as round 2 rolls out many more will benefit as well.
Outcome 2
- More than five risk reduction activities have been introduced to operators across the TDAs - All initial awareness activities have been completed and systematic training has been provided to each operator across the 6 TDAs for climate change risk reduction. - More than 80% of the targeted communities have adopted climate resilient livelihoods by taking long term measures to climate change risks.
- Apia Lua was awarded the works for the construction of the Manase Shoreline Protection Project whereas the Manase Beach Protection Project was re-tendered in Q1.
- The small grants scheme first call for proposals conducted the first and second monitoring successfully through the focal points under STA. According to the recommendation from the MTE report, the project recruited the Sustainable Tourism expert to assist with the Small Grant Scheme round 2. An awareness workshop for round 2 of the Small grants scheme was carried out for those eligible under the 6 TDA's. Application forms and guidelines were also distributed during the awareness workshops. 16 projects was approved and 2 were approved in principal pending site visit. The project recruited Kramer as the project designer and supervisor for the preparation of detailed design, concept plans and costing for the proposals that come in.
- the MTE for the project was conducted and completed this year in Q2. The PM resigned in Q1 for another life commitment and the Principal Technical Officer was recruited who was later appointed the PM. Mr. Isamaeli Time.
- NIWAs contract for the CLEWS was signed and they produced the situation analysis repor

Outcome 1 - By the end of the project, at least 6 climate resilient management plans have been developed and operationalized per TDA, involving at least 20 villages in total. - By the end of the project, at least 75% of the targeted tourism operators apply the issued guidelines; - By the end of the project, at least 15 operators have successfully gained access to financial products for climate resilient actions
Outcome 2 - At least five risk reduction activities have been introduced across the 9 villages in the 6 TDAs; - By the end of the project at least 50% of the women and 50% of the men of the targeted communities has been trained in climate risk reduction. - By the end of the project at least 80% of the targeted communities have adopted climate resilient livelihoods.

description.narrative: Increase the resilience of the tourism sector of Samoa through mainstreaming climate risks into tourismrelated policy processes which guide the implementation of adaptation actions by tourism operators and tourism reliant communities

Capacity perception index of STA disaggregated by gender AMAT 222
1no capacity built
2initial awareness raised
3substantial training in practical application
4knowledge effectively transferred
5ability to apply or disseminate knowledge demonstrated

comment.narrative: Capacity of STA is currently rated at 23
By the end of the project the capacity is 45

At the end of this review period the rated capacity of the STA has progressed to 3 4 This is due to the involvement of staff in the project workshops carried out during the reported period The Participatory Three 3 Dimensional Model workshops conducted during the formulation of the TDA Management Plans brought STA staff to learn and participate in this key part of the project

description.narrative: of tourism operators who invest and implement sustainable adaptation measures to enhance their resilience

comment.narrative: Tourism operators are not investing in sustainable adaptation measures but instead in quick and unsustainable measures to cope with climate risks
At least 75 of all tourism operators in the 6 targeted TDAs have invested and implemented sustainable adaptation measures

An approximate of 30 of operators in the TDAs are investing in sustainable adaptation measures Operators have learned of the importance of replanting initiatives Manase operators for instance had not opted for a rock seawall for protection through gained knowledge that this will speed up erosion resulting in total loss of their beach Villages in the TDAs have also reported that sandmining has been banned for commercial use and monitored by the village council and are supported by some of the village bylaws for the villages who have completed these
Furthermore the beach fale operator at Satuiatua which is one of the TDAs on Savaii has been advocating in their village to stop the removal of the beach rocks along the shore

description.narrative: Climate change adaptation mainstreamed into tourismrelated policy instruments and publicprivate partnerships
of Management Plans developed and operationalized

comment.narrative: Climate resilient management plans are currently not in place
By the end of the project at least 6 climate resilient management plans have been developed and operationalized per TDA involving at least 20 villages in total
The project has received 6 draft TDA Management Plans from the Water Technology company The project is currently undertaking its first review

description.narrative: of tourism operators in targeted TDAs apply new guidelines for climate resilient actions

comment.narrative: No guidelines exist for effective noregrets adaptation measures to increase resilience of tourism operators and there is a history of little application of guidelines is commonly low
By the end of the project at least 75 of the targeted tourism operators apply the issued guidelines
The Guidelines are currently being drafted and hope foreseen to be finalized once received by mid July 2015

description.narrative: of tourism operators that gain access to financial products for climate resilient actions

comment.narrative: Tourism operators do not access financial products for climate resilient actions
By the end of the project at least 15 operators have successfully gained access to financial products for climate resilient actions

At the moment the Small Grants Scheme Guidelines are being drafted and finalised to roll out the funds for climate resilient activities Informal agreement and discussions took place with the PSSF Private Sector Support Facility for channelling funds in respect of environmental safeguards A Small Grant facilitator will be hired by the project to streamline the process of channelling grants and implementation of climate resilient actions Operators are eagerly awaiting the opportunity through the Small Grants component of the project to assist with the climate resilient projects

description.narrative: Increased adaptive capacity to climate change and disaster risks of tourismreliant communites
Number and type of risk reduction activities introduced in tourism reliant communities AMAT 2311

comment.narrative: No Operators with Business plans which incorporate climate smart risk assessment planning
At least five risk reduction activities have been introduced across the 9 villages in the 6 TDAs

At the moment the Manase Detailed Design for Beach Replenishment and control for coastal protection is currently underway which will benefit the whole village of Manase Beach fale operators at Saleapaga in south east Upolu have also with the assistance of other line projects completed an evacuation route that will benefit the whole village of Saleapaga

description.narrative: of targeted tourism reliant communities that have adopted climate resilient livelihoods

comment.narrative: Apart from some adhoc measures individuals are taking none of the targeted communities have climate resilient livelihoods
By the end of the project at least 80 of the targeted communities have adopted climate resilient livelihoods

Targeted TDAs are adopting climate resilient livelihoods and are starting with relocation of some of the key infrastructures in the safe zones such as the ones on the south eastern side of Upolu Saleapaga and Lalomanu as a result of information received through the project Some of the operators at Manase have started to move some of their assets further away from the beach Plantation tours visit to nearby attractions including cultural and natural sites such as the Mt Matavanu crater caves pools and village walks have also been considered as key activities for tourists to complement the beach experience

description.narrative: of women and men in tourism reliant communities trained in climate risk reduction

comment.narrative: Initial awareness raising activities have taken place in the project area under the PPG phase but no systematic training has been provided on
By the end of the project at least 50 of the women and 50 of the men of the targeted communities has been trained in climate risk reduction

An integrated training program for the TDAs targeted has been recommended under the TDA Management Plans to be part of the wider Samoa Tourism Support Programme STSP The CLEWS component of this project will also hold workshops and trainings for the TDAs Introductory information was provided through the Tourism Cyclone Recovery Programme TCRP Financial Risk Management assessment on geo hazards and climate futures Women and men have been consistently equally present at the workshops conducted The P3D model workshops held in each TDA to inform the Management plans have also served to train communities on the most threatening climate risks with specific reference to each particular geographical context

title.narrative: 00079044_Economywide integration of climate change adaptation and disaster risk

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDPs results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDPs projects contributed to

Total number of disaster risk reduction and/or integrated disaster risk reduction and adaptation plans, and dedicated institutional frameworks and multi-stakeholder coordination mechanisms, are in place
total number of legislative or regulatory provisions for DRM (including CRM)
number of legislative or regulatory provisions for DRM (including CRM) that are effective

Economy-wide integration of Climate Change Adaptation to allow for increased integration of climate change adaptation and disaster risk management into national development planning and programming across all sectors.
capital of a political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

Project Objective: 1. Increased capacity within GoS for coordination of cross-sectoral actions for climate change adaptation, including planning, budgeting, implementing and monitoring and evaluating. 2. Integration of climate change adaptation and DRM into the Strategy for the Development of Samoa 20172021.
Outcome 1.1: 1.1.1. Sector plans that include specific budgets for adaptation actions [adapted from AMAT 1.1.1] 1.1.2. Formulation and endorsement of National Climate Change Adaptation Strategy.
Outcome 1.2: 1.2.1. Increase in number of community-managed projects for adaptation to climate risks.
Outcome 2.1: 2.1.1. Number of people benefitting from improved flood management through implementation of hard and soft measures for protection of community assets. [AMAT 1.2.15]. 2.1.2. Number of people with increased income compared to the control group as a result of diversified livelihood practices and more secure access to livelihood assets, disaggregated by age and gender 2.1.3. Number of people adopting household-level processing facilities transferred to targeted groups disaggregated by age and gender [adapted from AMAT 3.1.1]
Outcome 2.2: 2.2.1. Number of villages covered by Village Disaster Risk Management plans to reduce risks of and respond to climate variability [adapted from AMAT 2.2.1]
Outcome 3.1: 3.1.1. Increased capacity of government staff to access information on climate and disaster risks as well as M&E on climate change adaptation.

comment.narrative:
Project Objective: 1. Capacity for national coordination of climate change adaptation and DRM is presently limited (Level 3: Partially developed capacity). 2. Integration of climate change adaptation and DRM in the Strategy for the Development of Samoa 20122016 is limited.
Outcome 1.1: 1.1.1. At present, 4 sector plans do not include climate change adaptation. 1.1.2. There is presently no National Climate Change Adaptation Strategy.
Outcome 1.2: 1.2.1. Few community-managed projects for adaptation to climate risks. 1.2.2. No monitoring of public expenditure on climate change adaptation.
Outcome 2.1: 2.1.1. No people benefit from improved flood management from climate-resilient flood protection measures introduced in Vaisigano River catchment for protection of community assets. 2.1.2. No difference in income between targeted and control groups owing to diversified livelihoods and secure access to livelihood assets. 2.1.3. No people have adopted and utilised household-level processing facilities to support diversified livelihoods
Outcome 2.2: 2.2.1. No Village Disaster Risk Management Plans implemented by the project.
Outcome 3.1: 3.1.1. Low capacity of government staff to access information on climate and disaster risks as well as M&E on climate change adaptation.

Project Objective: 1. By end of project, GoS will have sufficient capacity for effective coordination of cross-sectoral actions for CCA (Level5:fully developed 2. The Strategy for the Development of Samoa 20172021 will include key performance indicators for climate change adaptation for outcomes relating to agriculture, community development, water and sanitation, transport and climate and disaster resilience.
Outcome 1.1 1.1.1. All 15 sector plans are formulated to include climate change adaptation and are approved by the end of the project. 1.1.2. A National Climate Change Adaptation Strategy is formulated and endorsed by the end of the project.
Outcome 1.2 1.2.1. At least 20 community-managed projects for adaptation to climate risks. 1.2.2. MoF-CRICU and MNRE-CCU have improved capacity to monitor expenditure on climate change adaptation.
Outcome 2.12.1.1. At least 12,000 people benefit from improved flood management from climate-resilient flood protection measures introduced in Vaisigano River catchment for protection of community assets (6,000 male and 6,000 female). 2.1.2. At least 600 beneficiaries adopting diversified livelihoods have demonstrable increases in income compared to the control group owing to more secure access to livelihood assets (at least 400 women irrespective of age and 200 youth irrespective of gender). 2.1.3. At least 600 beneficiaries participating in project interventions adopt and utilise household-level processing facilities to support diversified livelihoods (at least 400 women irrespective of age and at least 200 youth irrespective of gender).
Outcome 2.2 2.2.1. At least 100 Village Disaster Risk Management Plans implemented by the project.
Outcome 3.1 3.1.1. By the end of the project, key officials from MNRE-CCU and MoF-CRICU will have sufficient capacity for accessing information on climate and disaster risks as well as M&E on climate change adaptation (Level 5: Fully developed capacity).

Project Objective: 1. Three project steering committee meetings chaired by Ministry of Finance with, LDCF, AF and PPCR were held in 2016. Four Technical Advisory Group (TAG) meetings have been organized in 2016. Main issues discussed and resolved, reallocation of component 1 to include review of National Building Code. The funding from the output 1.2 has been used for the building code as per agreement form MOF. Three TA's to carry out this work - this includes legal writer, technical writer, architectural designer. Discussions of quarterly progress, endorsement of quarterly workplan and budget are carried out in this platform with regards to the EWACC project developments. 2. A platform within the Ministry through its environmental sector coordination which aligns sectoral priorities are integrated to be reflected in the national development strategy. Reporting to the environmental coordination for integration into the National Environment Sector Plan 2017-2021 is consistent.
Outcome 1.1 1.1.1. A new Environment Sector Plan (2017-2020) includes the mainstreaming of climate change adaptation and disaster risk management, as it is one of the four main longer outcome included in the NESP. Developments through the Environment Sector as a pathway to the delivery of this output activity to meet the overall outcome in the early stages of this project 1.1.2. A matrix of all adaptation projects in Samoa initiated for this work
Outcome 1.2 1.2.1. ToR for benefit analysis tool prepared and consulted to guide the procurement of a technical assistant to implement this activity. 1.2.2. Initial preparations and discussions guided towards the development of this output is aligned with the leading implementing agencies priorities so that it meets the proposed outcome to be achieved. Currently, a draft terms of reference is available for review by the ministry of environment and finance with the assistance of UNDP be fore progressing to procure the consultancy services for thi

Project Objective: 1. By end of project, GoS will have sufficient capacity for effective coordination of cross-sectoral actions for CCA (Level5:fully developed 2. The Strategy for the Development of Samoa 20172021 will include key performance indicators for climate change adaptation for outcomes relating to agriculture, community development, water and sanitation, transport and climate and disaster resilience.
Outcome 1.1 1.1.1. All 15 sector plans are formulated to include climate change adaptation and are approved by the end of the project. 1.1.2. A National Climate Change Adaptation Strategy is formulated and endorsed by the end of the project.
Outcome 1.2 1.2.1. At least 20 community-managed projects for adaptation to climate risks. 1.2.2. MoF-CRICU and MNRE-CCU have improved capacity to monitor expenditure on climate change adaptation.
Outcome 2.12.1.1. At least 12,000 people benefit from improved flood management from climate-resilient flood protection measures introduced in Vaisigano River catchment for protection of community assets (6,000 male and 6,000 female). 2.1.2. At least 600 beneficiaries adopting diversified livelihoods have demonstrable increases in income compared to the control group owing to more secure access to livelihood assets (at least 400 women irrespective of age and 200 youth irrespective of gender). 2.1.3. At least 600 beneficiaries participating in project interventions adopt and utilise household-level processing facilities to support diversified livelihoods (at least 400 women irrespective of age and at least 200 youth irrespective of gender).
Outcome 2.2 2.2.1. At least 100 Village Disaster Risk Management Plans implemented by the project.
Outcome 3.1 3.1.1. By the end of the project, key officials from MNRE-CCU and MoF-CRICU will have sufficient capacity for accessing information on climate and disaster risks as well as M&E on climate change adaptation (Level 5: Fully developed capacity).

Project Objective: 1. There is continuous quarterly meetings for the National Steering Committee (NSC), which is the decision making body chaired by Ministry of Finance(MoF) and coordinated by the Climate Resilience Investment and Coordination Division (MoF-CRICD) for projects namely; Adaptation Fund, LDCF EWACC, Pacific Programme on Climate Resilience, PREP and the GCF Vaisigano Catchment Project. Reporting of progress from EWACC are also reported to these meetings. There have been four (4) Technical Advisory group meetings (TAG) held within 2017 to monitor progress and guide implementation of the project. Issues at the operational level are also discussed and resolved in this meeting and directs follow up actions and work in the following quarter 2. The Samoa Development Strategy (SDS) 2016/17- 2019/20 has included in the strategic outcomes the disaster and climate resilience for the SDS outcomes in agriculture, education, community, transport, health, water and environment sectors. The EWACC also reports to the National Environment Sector Steering Committee which is responsible for the monitoring of environment sector which also aligns in its long term outcomes the mainstreaming of Climate and disaster resilience as its priority area 4.
Outcome 1.1 1.1.1. In its M&E framework for the current SDS, Climate and disaster resilience management mainstreamed into strategic outcomes for SDS key outcomes such as, agriculture, health, education community development, water and sanitation, transport and environment. 1.1.2. The outline and concept for the development of the National Climate Change Adaptation Strategy is developed. Development of the National Adaptation Plan is also in pipeline for the next reporting period so that these policy papers are developed within the timeframe of the project.
Outcome 1.2 1.2.1. The roll out of the CDCRM programme to villages enhances the capacity of communities to be resilient to disaster and adverse impacts of climate change th

description.narrative: The Samoa One UN YEP project is responding to the request from the Government of Samoa to assist in addressing youth unemployment. Its main objective is to assist youth to develop knowledge and skills needed to enter the formal labour market.

title.narrative: Consultanty Services for a Mid Term Evaluator for the YEP Project

description.narrative: The One-UN Samoa Youth Employment Programme (1UN-YEP) is responding to the request from the Government of Samoa to assist in its ongoing efforts to address youth unemployment.

participating-org.narrative: UNITED NATIONS EDUCATIONAL, SCIENTIFIC & CULTURAL ORGANIZAITON

description.narrative: capital of a political entity
policy, planning and administration

provider-org.narrative: UNITED NATIONS EDUCATIONAL, SCIENTIFIC & CULTURAL ORGANIZAITON
UNITED NATIONS EDUCATIONAL, SCIENTIFIC & CULTURAL ORGANIZAITON

description.narrative: 1.a.i) National e-platform labour market information system linking different databases to provide a comprehensive picture with information relevant to the need of both and employers and job-seekers. 1.a.ii) Number of youth registered on national e-platform labour market information system, disaggregated by gender, village, age and educational status. 1.b Database of completed profiles of community-based youth uploaded to national e-platform labour market information systems. 1.c.i) an integrated system signposting youth job-seekers to services from a range of providers. 1.c.ii) New careers development services created in response to needs of youth transitioning to the labour market.

comment.narrative: 1.a There is no integrated national level e-platform of labour market information. 1.b SNYC do not maintain a database of youth profiles with employment information. 1.c No system to integrate and coordinate existing career development services and create new ones in response to youth needs.

1.1 All SNYC staff receive training and capacity building inputs on systems and processes for YEN e-platform operation. 1.2 YEN E-platform business-to-business functionality is designed through consultative process with SNYC, MWCSD, MCIL and CoC. 1.3 At least 25 businesses engage in regular business-to-business communication through YEN eplatform.

At least 800 youth, 50% of whom are females are registered on the YEN e-platform At least 50 youth are able to secure employment through alignment of skills to employment demands in the labour market system

1.1 A NYVS is designed through consultative process with SNYC, MCIL and MWCSD. 1.2 At least 100 youth, 50 per cent of whom are female, register and gain volunteer experience that enhances their employability.
40 secondary/PSET youth & 60 unemployed youth placed under internship program with public and private sector. At least 100 youth trained with soft skills and training relevant to employment demands

description.narrative: Improving the Performance and Reliability of Renewable Energy Power Systems in Samoa Project Initiation Plan for the Project Preparation Grant
capital of a political entity

Status of Project Approval and initiation

comment.narrative: Draft Project Proposal available

The LFA workshop was conducted on 11-13th May 2016. The project partners took part in discussion of the framework design and issues and concerns on what is impacting the realisation of Samoas 100% RE target. this was completed successfully with the RTA leading the discussion.
All the reports as well as the project Document was submitted to the RTA for the GEF Sec in December 2016.
Finalize any comments on the ProDoc proposal from the GEF and resubmit the proposal for approval of funds. Conduct the LPAC when approval is granted.

The project was cleared and approved by GEF in June 2017. the Project had its LPAC meeting on the 7th July and the DoA was issues on the 17th July for the project. There is a full size project profile that was also created that is separate from this PPG stage.

title.narrative: Green Climate Fund Vaisigano River Catchment

description.narrative: Integrated Flood Management to Enhance Climate Resilience of the Vaisigano River Catchment in Samoa

title.narrative: Integrated Flood Management to Enhance Climate Resilience of the Vaisigano River Catchment in Samoa
GCF SAM 001/17- Consultancy services for the Provision of a Review Assessment of the Interdependence of Flood Mitigation Options for the Vaisigano River Catchment in Samoa

description.narrative: The objective of the project is to strengthen the adaptive capacity, and the reduce exposure to extreme weather events of vulnerable communities, infrastructure, and the built environment in the Vaisigano River Catchment area.
capital of a political entity

1. Number physical assets made more resilient to climate variability and change, considering human benefits 1. Value of physical assets made more resilient to climate variability and change, considering human benefits 2. Use by vulnerable households, communities, businesses and public sector services of Fund supported tools, instruments, strategies and activities to respond to climate change and variability. 3. Number of males and females (and percentage of total population) reached by climate related early warning systems established/ strengthened 4. Number of sectoral plans and studies developed and/or adopted aligned to the IWMP. 5. Number of technical and extension officers trained on flood-related EWS data collection and interpretation 6. Number of people benefit from improved flood management through implementation of hard and soft measures for protection of community assets (set by gender) 7. Number of people reached by flood -related early warning systems established (separate by gender). 8. Number of households served with flood-proofed drainage in Vaisigano River Catchment

comment.narrative: 1. Number single engineered river works solutions to minimize and to withstand flooding exists in Segments 2, 3 and 4 in the Vaisigano River. 2. Currently, residents and economic assets located in the AUA lack protection from extreme flooding of the Vaisigano River 3. Currently the EWS covers only tsunami and earthquake warnings 4. Limited number of sectoral plans and projects to centrally plan drainage. No feasibility studies prepared for better rain and wastewater storage. 5. Limited capacity exists for technicians to interpret early warning data instruments and utilize for flood related response 6. Number of people benefit from flood management from climate resilient flood protection measures introduced in Vaisigano River catchment for protection of community assets. 7. The current EWS does not cover floods. 8. Currently, hazard areas exist within the AUA have inadequate drainage systems to withstand high volumes of water

1. Completed Channelization of Segments 2, 3 and 4 of the Vaisigano River, Construction upgrade of Lelata bridge, Extension of floodwalls at Lelata and Leone Bridges and at least 40 M dedicated to climate proof segment 2, 3 &4 and drainage works in AUA. 2. At least 26,528 residents located in the AUA are protected by flood management interventions. 3. At least 26,528 residents located in the AUA receive EWS for flooding. 4. 4 sectoral plans / studies developed/adopted for key sectors in the Greater Apia Catchment (Roads, Drainage, Reservoir, Water supply, etc.) aligned to the IWMP. 5. At least 300 technicians will be trained on EWS related to flooding. 6, At least 26,528 people benefit from improved flood management from climate-resilient flood protection measures introduced in Vaisigano River Catchment for protection of community assets (separate gender). 7. At least 26,528 people benefit from EWS coverage related to flooding alerts in Apia. 8. At least 5,000 households benefit from flood-proofed drainage in Apia.

1. Work has begun on the channelization and flood walls 2. No new credible data available as project has just begun 3. No new credible data available as project has just begun 4. No new credible data available as project has just begun 5. No new credible data available as project has just begun 6. No new credible data available as project has just begun 7. No new credible data available as project has just begun 8. No new credible data available as project has just begun

description.narrative: The objective of the project is the improved sustainable and cost-effective utilization of indigenous renewable energy resources for energy production in Samoa.

title.narrative: Imrpoving the Performance and Reliability of RE Power System in Samoa (IMPRESS)

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDPs results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDPs projects contributed to
Total number of plans and programmes that are informed by multi-hazard national and sub-national disaster and climate risk assessments
number of plans and programmes that are informed by risk assessments that differentiate impact on men and women
Improve the Performance and Reliability of RE Power System in Samoa (IMPRESS) Full Size Project
capital of a political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

a) Cumulative electricity generation using RE resources, GWh b) Cumulative GHG emission reduction, tCO2. c) Cumulative number of households benefitting from RE-based electricity generation and EE technology applications.

comment.narrative: a) 80 b) 7,832 c) zero
1. Complete the Inception Workshop for the project 2. Complete at least one regulation or policy review on RE and EE 3. Conduct at least 1 project awareness activity

The project document was signed on the 2nd August 2017 by the Government of Samoa and UNDP followed by its inception workshop on the 31st October 2017. The Inception report is in draft and yet to be endorsed at the TAG meeting in Q1 2018. The Eu-GIZ project who is a co-financer to the IMPRESS project has completed the review of the draft Energy Management Bill. Component of the EU-GIZ project aims to improve the legislative framework in the energy sector that ties to the IMPRESS project. The Samoa Energy Sector Plan 2017-2022 was also launched in October 2017.
The project supported the Samoa National Energy Awareness Day on November 29. This initiative was co-hosted by the MNRE and MoF. The project launched the winner of the IMPRESS Project Logo competition on this day. The project also showcased banners and other merchandise such as pens and bags.

title.narrative: Increase Political Participation of Women in Samoa

description.narrative: Increase Political Participation of Women in Samoa (IPPWS) Phase II builds on the successful achievements from Phase I and to support efforts to mobilize resources for its implementation.

description.narrative: Sub-Regional SDGs Localization designed to strengthen the weakness seen already in terms of planning and budgeting as well as monitoring and evaluation of the SDGs.
capital of a political entity
1.1. Number of SDGs Roadmaps & M&E Frameworks completed 1.2. National SDGs Task Forces showing strong ownership and leadership.

comment.narrative: Cook Islands NSDP, 2016-2020, closely aligned to SDGs. Niue has no SDGs National Task Force and no SDGs road map developed. Samoa Assessment of SDGs alignment to SDS conducted in 2016 and reported to N HLPF in July 2016. Tokelau has no SDGs road map developed and only started to consider mapping. M&E is weak throughout Government systems as shown in Quality of Life Report, 2014.
1.1 SDGs Roadmaps & M&E Frameworks completed for 4 PICs 1.2 4 established National SDGs Task Forces showing strong ownership and leadership.
1.1 Draft Roadmap completed for 1 PICs 1.2 1 established National SDGs Task Force
